Distributed Algorithms for Spectrum Allocation, Power Control, Routing, and Congestion Control in Wireless Networks

Yufang Xi and Edmund M. Yeh
Department of Electrical Engineering
Yale University
New Haven, CT 06520, USA
Email: {yufang.xi, edmund.yeh}@yale.edu
Abstract

We develop distributed algorithms to allocate resources in multi-hop wireless networks with the aim of minimizing total cost. In order to observe the fundamental duplexing constraint that co-located transmitters and receivers cannot operate simultaneously on the same frequency band, we first devise a spectrum allocation scheme that divides the whole spectrum into multiple sub-bands and activates conflict-free links on each sub-band. We show that the minimum number of required sub-bands grows asymptotically at a logarithmic rate with the chromatic number of network connectivity graph. A simple distributed and asynchronous algorithm is developed to feasibly activate links on the available sub-bands. Given a feasible spectrum allocation, we then design node-based distributed algorithms for optimally controlling the transmission powers on active links for each sub-band, jointly with traffic routes and user input rates in response to channel states and traffic demands. We show that under specified conditions, the algorithms asymptotically converge to the optimal operating point.

11footnotetext: This research is supported in part by NSF grant CNS-0626882 and AFOSR grant FA9550-06-1-0135.

I Introduction

While offering the potential for ubiquitous and untethered communications, wireless networks typically demand more sophisticated resource management than wireline networks. Optimal resource allocation in large-scale wireless networks involves joint optimization across multiple layers as well as distributed implementation across network nodes. In this paper, we develop distributed algorithms which jointly allocate frequency spectrum, transmission powers, traffic input rates, and traffic routes on a node-by-node basis in order to minimize total cost in an interference-limited multi-hop wireless network.

While joint optimization involving power control, congestion control, and routing has been studied previously [1, 2, 3], a common shortcoming of the previous work is the failure to account for the constraint that a node cannot transmit and receive simultaneously on the same frequency band. For while some types of multi-user interference can be ameliorated by using advanced coding techniques, interference between a transmitter and a co-located receiver is very difficult to suppress due to the transmitted power being many orders of magnitude higher than the received power at the same node.222Theoretically a node is able to subtract the transmission signals generated by itself from the received signals so that the self-interference can be perfectly cancelled out. In real decoders, however, the received signals are practically irrecoverable in the face of the overwhelming transmitted signals. The resulting constraint that a transmitter cannot be simultaneously active with a co-located receiver [4] on the same frequency band is referred to as the duplexing constraint. In practical wireless networks, the duplexing constraint appears to be quite fundamental, and thus must be observed by resource management schemes.

In this paper, we develop distributed resource allocation algorithms for wireless networks in accordance with the duplexing constraint. To accomplish this, we first devise a new spectrum allocation scheme which divides the spectrum into a sufficient number of frequency bands and activates co-located transmitters and receivers on different bands. We show that the minimum number of sub-bands needed for resolving duplexing conflicts is asymptotically logarithmic in the chromatic number333The chromatic number of a graph is the minimum number of colors with which the vertices of the graph can be colored such that adjacent vertices have different colors. of the network connectivity graph. We provide a simple algorithm that feasibly assigns frequency bands to links in a distributed and asynchronous manner with low control overhead.

Given a conflict-free spectrum allocation, we then design a set of node-based distributed gradient projection algorithms that iteratively adjust transmission powers, traffic input rates, and traffic routes according to channel conditions and traffic demands, in order to minimize total network cost. The power control and routing algorithms we develop are frequency selective, in that for each link, the power control algorithm adjusts the transmission power on each of the link’s active sub-bands. The routing algorithm involves both inter-node routing, which specifies the allocation of incoming traffic at each node to its outgoing links, and intra-node routing, which specifies the allocation of the total traffic on a given link across its active sub-bands. Finally, we show that congestion control can be naturally incorporated by considering an equivalent routing problem on a virtual overflow link. We show that under specified conditions, the iterative algorithms converge to the optimal operating point from any initial condition.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the network model, discuss the duplexing constraint, and formulate the spectrum allocation problem. In Section III, we find the minimum number of sub-bands required by a feasible spectrum allocation. A distributed and asynchronous sub-band allocation algorithm is developed in Section IV. In Section V, we formulate the cross-layer optimization problem for networks operating on multiple sub-bands, and derive the conditions satisfied by the optimal configuration. In Section VI, we present node-based gradient projection algorithms to jointly optimize power control, routing, and congestion control based on the outcome of the spectrum allocation, as well as the channel conditions and traffic demands of the network.

II Network Model and Spectrum Allocation

Let the wireless network be modelled by a directed and connected graph 𝒢=(𝒩,ℒ)𝒢𝒩ℒ\mathcal{G}=({\cal N},{\cal L}), where 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is referred to as the connectivity graph of the network. A node i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N} represents a wireless transceiver, and (i,j)∈ℒ𝑖𝑗ℒ(i,j)\in{\cal L} represents a unidirectional wireless link from node i𝑖i to j𝑗j. We assume 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is link-symmetric, i.e., if (i,j)∈ℒ𝑖𝑗ℒ(i,j)\in{\cal L}, then (j,i)∈ℒ𝑗𝑖ℒ(j,i)\in{\cal L}, and vice versa. Two nodes i𝑖i and j𝑗j are neighbors if (i,j)∈ℒ𝑖𝑗ℒ(i,j)\in{\cal L} (or equivalently (j,i)∈ℒ𝑗𝑖ℒ(j,i)\in{\cal L}). Let 𝒪i≜{j:(i,j)∈ℒ}≜subscript𝒪𝑖conditional-set𝑗𝑖𝑗ℒ{\cal O}_{i}\triangleq\{j:(i,j)\in{\cal L}\} be the set of i𝑖i’s neighbors.

II-A Duplexing Constrained Interference Model

We focus on a network model that prohibits any node from simultaneously transmitting and receiving on the same frequency band. That is, we impose the duplexing constraint on every band. Such a constraint is less stringent but more fundamental than the extensively studied primary interference constraint [5, 6, 7], where any node can transmit or receive (at any given time and on any given band) on at most one active link, and the secondary interference constraint, which further prohibits any node from transmitting when there is a neighbor receiving from another node [8]. A general approach to studying a broad class of interference constraints was presented in [9]. Indeed, duplexing constraints cannot be bypassed (at least currently) by using sophisticated coding methods, and must be observed by practical network management techniques.

Traditional network management techniques which aim to resolve various types of interference among wireless links have concentrated on scheduling in time [10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17], where at any given time, only mutually-non-interfering links are activated. Scheduling, however, usually requires centralized controllers and involves high communication and computational complexity [7, 18]. Simplified distributed scheduling policies have been proposed [19, 8, 20, 5, 6] for various purposes. In general, however, the reduced implementation complexity comes at the expense of performance [21].

The difficulty in finding interference-free schedules in time leads us to seek an alternative solution. A natural approach is to consider network management in the domain of frequency instead of or in addition to time [22, 23, 24, 25]. Because communication on different frequency bands are practically non-interfering, one can think of simultaneously applying different link activation sets on non-overlapping frequency bands within the assigned spectrum. In this scheme, nodes transmit on certain bands while receiving on other bands to avoid duplexing interference. The spectrum allocation technique has an important advantage over scheduling in time: once a feasible spectrum allocation is established, the network can function relatively statically in that mode, not having to switch to another mode unless network itself changes substantially. While spectrum allocation problems have been proposed and studied in the interference graph induced by particular interference constraints, the solution using existing vertex-coloring methods [22, 23] is cumbersome and its complexity scales poorly with the size of the network. Moreover, the optimization of frequency assignment techniques has not been thoroughly investigated. In particular, the number of available frequency bands is often arbitrarily set and frequency bands are assigned to links in a heuristic manner [24, 25].

In this work, we adopt the spectrum allocation approach to resolve the fundamental duplexing conflicts for general wireless networks. In particular, we investigate two central questions: (1) what is the minimum number of frequency bands with which all co-located transmitters and receivers can be simultaneously activated subject to duplexing constraints, and (2) how can one efficiently find a feasible frequency assignment when there are enough frequency bands? We provide an exact analytical answer to question (1) and develop a distributed asynchronous algorithm which solves problem (2). Our analysis is based only the network connectivity graph. This approach requires much less storage and computation overhead than alternative methods that utilize the interference graph.

II-B Spectrum Division and Sub-band Allocation

The duplexing constraint permits only a subset of the links to be activated simultaneously on each frequency band. To activate all links at the same time, it is necessary to divide the spectrum into several sub-bands and activate different subsets of conflict-free links on different sub-bands.

Suppose the network occupies a contiguous spectrum which can be partitioned into a number, say Q𝑄Q, of sub-bands, each of which covers a contiguous segment of the whole spectrum. Let the collection of the sub-bands be denoted by 𝒬𝒬{\cal Q}. With a specific spectrum division in place, each link can be active on one or more of the sub-bands. If link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) uses sub-band q𝑞q, we say (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) is an active link on q𝑞q, and q𝑞q is an active sub-band of (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j). Denote the subset of links that are active on a sub-band q𝑞q by ℒqsubscriptℒ𝑞{\cal L}_{q}, and the set of active sub-bands of (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) by 𝒬i​jsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑗{\cal Q}_{ij}. A spectrum allocation is given by the collection {ℒq}q∈𝒬subscriptsubscriptℒ𝑞𝑞𝒬\{{\cal L}_{q}\}_{q\in{\cal Q}} (or equivalently {𝒬i​j}(i,j)∈ℒsubscriptsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗ℒ\{{\cal Q}_{ij}\}_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}}). Note that finding a spectrum allocation involves two steps: spectrum division, which decides how many sub-bands the whole spectrum is divided into, and sub-band allocation, which determines which links are active on which sub-bands. We will address these two issues in Sections III and IV, respectively.

A spectrum allocation is feasible if (i) for all (i,j)∈ℒ𝑖𝑗ℒ(i,j)\in{\cal L}, 𝒬i​j≠∅subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗{\cal Q}_{ij}\neq\emptyset, and (ii) for all q∈𝒬𝑞𝒬q\in{\cal Q}, ℒqsubscriptℒ𝑞{\cal L}_{q} satisfies the duplexing constraint. Thus, any node’s outgoing and incoming links cannot be both active on the same sub-band. However, it is feasible for a node to have multiple active outgoing links or multiple active incoming links on a single sub-band.

II-C Interference Graph and Number of Sub-bands

In previous studies on frequency assignment techniques, the minimum number of frequency bands is found from the interference graph induced by the specific interference constraints [22, 23]. For the duplexing constraints, the interference graph 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G} is constructed as follows. Let the vertices of the interference graph 𝒢~=(𝒱,ℰ)~𝒢𝒱ℰ\tilde{\cal G}=({\cal V},{\cal E}) be the links of the network connectivity graph 𝒢=(𝒩,ℒ)𝒢𝒩ℒ{\cal G}=({\cal N},{\cal L}), i.e., 𝒱=ℒ𝒱ℒ{\cal V}={\cal L}. In 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G}, an edge exists between two vertices (links in 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}) if one link’s transmitter is the other link’s receiver. The interference graph, unlike the connectivity graph, is undirected.444In order to avoid confusion, we refer to the connectivity graph as having nodes 𝒩𝒩{\cal N} and links ℒℒ{\cal L}, and the interference graph as having vertices 𝒱𝒱{\cal V} and edges ℰℰ{\cal E}. It is easy to see that a feasible spectrum allocation on 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} exists if and only if the number of available sub-bands is greater than or equal to the chromatic number χ​(𝒢~)𝜒~𝒢\chi(\tilde{\cal G}) of the interference graph 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G}. We illustrate the interference graph approach in Figure 1 using a complete four-node network. On the left is the connectivity graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, whose induced interference graph 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G} is shown in the middle. A minimal vertex-coloring on 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G} using four colors {R,G,B,Y}𝑅𝐺𝐵𝑌\{R,G,B,Y\} is depicted. The right graph represents the link-coloring on 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} inferred by the minimal vertex-coloring on 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G}. The color(s) associated with each node are those assigned to the outgoing links of that node. The reason for using such a representation will be explained shortly.

Although the interference graph approach can provide an answer to our problem, it has major shortcomings. Note that the size of the interference graph |𝒱|=|ℒ|𝒱ℒ|{\cal V}|=|{\cal L}| is on the order of |𝒩|2superscript𝒩2|{\cal N}|^{2}. To compute the chromatic number of 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G}, 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G} has to be constructed and stored at a central controller which then computes χ​(𝒢~)𝜒~𝒢\chi(\tilde{\cal G}) by finding a minimal vertex-coloring, which is itself an NP-complete problem [26]. For these reasons, the interference graph approach is not tractable for medium-and-large-scale networks. This motivates us to seek an alternative method that can find the minimum number of sub-bands directly from the connectivity graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}.

III Spectrum Division

In this section, we investigate the minimum number of sub-bands which yields a feasible spectrum allocation. Our analysis will be based entirely on the network connectivity graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. For convenience of exposition, we first transform the problem into an equivalent graph-theoretic link-coloring problem.

III-A Link-Coloring Problem

For the moment, we leave the total number of sub-bands undetermined. Let each sub-band be identified by a unique color. We represent a spectrum allocation by a color assignment to links. A feasible spectrum allocation corresponds to a color assignment such that (i) all links are assigned with at least one color and (ii) for any node, no incoming link has a common color with any one of its outgoing links. We will find the minimum number of colors required for such a coloring. For any color assignment, denote the set of colors used by node i𝑖i’s outgoing links by 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i}, and the set of colors used by its incoming links by ℐ​𝒞iℐsubscript𝒞𝑖{\cal IC}_{i}. Since the network is connected and link-symmetric, every node has at least one outgoing and one incoming link, implying that 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} and ℐ​𝒞iℐsubscript𝒞𝑖{\cal IC}_{i} are both nonempty for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N}. A color assignment is feasible if and only if 𝒪​𝒞i∩ℐ​𝒞i=∅𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖ℐsubscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i}\cap{\cal IC}_{i}=\emptyset for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N}.555Note that we allow one link to transmit on multiple sub-bands. Hence, we do not require |𝒪​𝒞i|≤|𝒪i|𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝒪𝑖|{\cal OC}_{i}|\leq|{\cal O}_{i}| or |ℐ​𝒞i|≤|𝒪i|ℐsubscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝒪𝑖|{\cal IC}_{i}|\leq|{\cal O}_{i}|. Note that the feasibility of a coloring scheme can be checked using the node color sets {𝒪​𝒞i,ℐ​𝒞i}i∈𝒩subscript𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖ℐsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖𝒩\{{\cal OC}_{i},{\cal IC}_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}}, regardless of the detailed assignment of colors to links. In fact, we will show that studying the node outgoing color sets {𝒪​𝒞i}𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\{{\cal OC}_{i}\} alone suffices for the link coloring problem. In the following, we say a color assignment is consistent with {𝒪​𝒞i}𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\{{\cal OC}_{i}\} if {𝒪​𝒞i}𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\{{\cal OC}_{i}\} results from the color assignment.

Lemma 1

Given a graph 𝒢={𝒩,ℒ}𝒢𝒩ℒ{\cal G}=\{{\cal N},{\cal L}\} and the nodes’ outgoing color sets {𝒪​𝒞i}i∈𝒩subscript𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝑖𝒩\{{\cal OC}_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}}, there exists a consistent and feasible color assignment if and only if

(i) 𝒪​𝒞i\𝒪​𝒞j≠∅\𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{i}\backslash{\cal OC}_{j}\neq\emptyset, for all (i,j)∈ℒ𝑖𝑗ℒ(i,j)\in{\cal L};

(ii) ⋃j∈𝒪i𝒪​𝒞i\𝒪​𝒞j=𝒪​𝒞isubscript𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖\𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\bigcup_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}{\cal OC}_{i}\backslash{\cal OC}_{j}={\cal OC}_{i}, for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N}.

Proof: We first prove the necessity part. Suppose first that (i) is violated, i.e., there exists a link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) such that 𝒪​𝒞i⊆𝒪​𝒞j𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{i}\subseteq{\cal OC}_{j}, then (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) must have a color in 𝒪​𝒞j𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{j}, meaning that some outgoing link of j𝑗j has the same color as (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j), which is infeasible. Next suppose that (ii) does not hold for some node i𝑖i, i.e., there exists a color q∈𝒪​𝒞i𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖q\in{\cal OC}_{i} such that q∈𝒪​𝒞j𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗q\in{\cal OC}_{j} of every j∈𝒪​𝒞i𝑗𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖j\in{\cal OC}_{i}. Since q𝑞q is used on some outgoing link of i𝑖i, say (i,k)𝑖𝑘(i,k), (i,k)𝑖𝑘(i,k) will have a color belonging to 𝒪​𝒞k𝒪subscript𝒞𝑘{\cal OC}_{k}, violating the duplexing constraint at node k𝑘k.

The conditions are sufficient because given {𝒪​𝒞i}i∈𝒩subscript𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝑖𝒩\{{\cal OC}_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}} which satisfy (i)-(ii), a feasible coloring can be constructed by assigning each link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) the color(s) in 𝒪​𝒞i\𝒪​𝒞j\𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{i}\backslash{\cal OC}_{j}. By (ii), this coloring is also consistent with {𝒪​𝒞i}i∈𝒩subscript𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝑖𝒩\{{\cal OC}_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}}. ∎

In the following, we use the shorthand notation 𝒪​𝒞i≁𝒪​𝒞jnot-similar-to𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{i}\nsim{\cal OC}_{j} to represent 𝒪​𝒞i\𝒪​𝒞j≠∅\𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{i}\backslash{\cal OC}_{j}\neq\emptyset and 𝒪​𝒞j\𝒪​𝒞i≠∅\𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{j}\backslash{\cal OC}_{i}\neq\emptyset. A collection of node outgoing color sets {𝒪​𝒞i}i∈𝒩subscript𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝑖𝒩\{{\cal OC}_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}} is said to be feasible if it satisfies the conditions in Lemma 1.

We now state the problem of finding the minimum number of sub-bands in terms of the minimal coloring problem as follows. Given a graph 𝒢=(𝒩,ℒ)𝒢𝒩ℒ{\cal G}=({\cal N},{\cal L}),

minimize |⋃i∈𝒩𝒪​𝒞i|subscript𝑖𝒩𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\displaystyle\left|\bigcup_{i\in{\cal N}}{\cal OC}_{i}\right| (1)

We will find a lower bound on Q𝒢∗superscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢Q_{\cal G}^{*} and a matching upper bound on Q𝒢subscript𝑄𝒢Q_{\cal G}, thus uniquely determining Q𝒢subscript𝑄𝒢Q_{\cal G}. For lower bounding Q𝒢∗superscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢Q_{\cal G}^{*}, the next observation is useful. The proof is deferred to Appendix -A.

Lemma 2

Let B1,⋯,Bksubscript𝐵1⋯subscript𝐵𝑘B_{1},\cdots,B_{k} be distinct subsets of a Q𝑄Q-set all of which have the same cardinality g𝑔g. If g>⌊Q/2⌋𝑔𝑄2g>\lfloor Q/2\rfloor, then there exist distinct subsets C1,⋯,Cksubscript𝐶1⋯subscript𝐶𝑘C_{1},\cdots,C_{k} such that Cj⊂Bjsubscript𝐶𝑗subscript𝐵𝑗C_{j}\subset B_{j} and |Cj|=g−1subscript𝐶𝑗𝑔1|C_{j}|=g-1, j=1,⋯,k𝑗1⋯𝑘j=1,\cdots,k. Lemma 3

There exists an optimal solution {Bi}i∈𝒩subscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑖𝒩\{B_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}} for (2) such that all Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}, i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N}, have the same cardinality.

Using Lemma 3, we can find a lower bound on Q𝒢∗superscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢Q_{\cal G}^{*} as follows.

Lemma 4

Given a graph 𝒢=(𝒩,ℒ)𝒢𝒩ℒ{\cal G}=({\cal N},{\cal L}) with chromatic number χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}), the solution Q𝒢∗superscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢Q_{\cal G}^{*} of the problem (2) is greater than or equal to Q​(χ​(𝒢))𝑄𝜒𝒢Q(\chi({\cal G})), where the function Q:ℤ+↦ℤ+:𝑄maps-tosubscriptℤsubscriptℤQ:\mathbb{Z}_{+}\mapsto\mathbb{Z}_{+} is defined as

Q​(N)≜min⁡{q∈ℤ+:(q⌊q/2⌋)≥N}.≜𝑄𝑁:𝑞subscriptℤbinomial𝑞𝑞2𝑁Q(N)\triangleq\min\left\{q\in\mathbb{Z}_{+}:~{}{{q}\choose{\lfloor{q/2}\rfloor}}\geq N\right\}. (3)

Proof: By Lemma 3, we can without loss of optimality consider a solution {Bi}i∈𝒩subscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑖𝒩\{B_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}} of (2) such that |Bi|=|Bj|subscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝐵𝑗|B_{i}|=|B_{j}|, for all i,j∈𝒩𝑖𝑗𝒩i,j\in{\cal N}. Therefore, Bi≁Bjnot-similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝐵𝑗B_{i}\nsim B_{j} whenever Bi≠Bjsubscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝐵𝑗B_{i}\neq B_{j}. Suppose there are K𝐾K distinct elements in {Bi}i∈𝒩subscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑖𝒩\{B_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}}. Because |⋃iBi|=Q𝒢∗subscript𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢|\bigcup_{i}B_{i}|=Q_{\cal G}^{*}, by Sperner’s theorem [27], K≤(Q𝒢∗⌊Q𝒢∗/2⌋)𝐾binomialsuperscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢superscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢2K\leq{Q_{\cal G}^{*}\choose\lfloor Q_{\cal G}^{*}/2\rfloor}. Moreover, since {Bi}subscript𝐵𝑖\{B_{i}\} satisfies the constraint in (2), we must have K≥χ​(𝒢)𝐾𝜒𝒢K\geq\chi({\cal G}), where χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}) is the chromatic number of 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. Therefore, Q𝒢∗≥Q​(χ​(𝒢))superscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢𝑄𝜒𝒢Q_{\cal G}^{*}\geq Q(\chi({\cal G})). ∎

Lemma 4 indicates that at least Q​(χ​(𝒢))𝑄𝜒𝒢Q(\chi({\cal G})) colors are needed to construct a feasible collection of node color sets even with the condition (ii) in Lemma 1 removed. However, by assigning node color sets according to a minimal node-labelling scheme of 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, Q​(χ​(𝒢))𝑄𝜒𝒢Q(\chi({\cal G})) colors are sufficient to yield a feasible configuration satisfying both conditions in Lemma 1. We can therefore conclude the following.

Lemma 5

Given a graph 𝒢=(𝒩,ℒ)𝒢𝒩ℒ{\cal G}=({\cal N},{\cal L}) with chromatic number χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}), the solution Q𝒢subscript𝑄𝒢Q_{\cal G} to the problem (1) is less than or equal to Q​(χ​(𝒢))𝑄𝜒𝒢Q(\chi({\cal G})).

Proof: For graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, Q​(χ​(𝒢))𝑄𝜒𝒢Q(\chi({\cal G})) colors are sufficient because they can generate at least χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}) color subsets {Bi}subscript𝐵𝑖\{B_{i}\} with equal cardinality ⌊Q​(χ​(𝒢))/2⌋𝑄𝜒𝒢2\lfloor Q(\chi({\cal G}))/2\rfloor, any two of which satisfy Bi≁Bjnot-similar-tosubscript𝐵𝑖subscript𝐵𝑗B_{i}\nsim B_{j}. Associate any χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}) of the color subsets with χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}) labels. Assign the χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}) color subsets to nodes according to a minimal node-labelling scheme, which requires exactly χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}) labels. We then have a feasible collection of node outgoing color sets that satisfies the two conditions in Lemma 1.666An arbitrary color subset assignment according to a node-labelling solution generally results in {𝒪​𝒞i}i∈𝒩subscript𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝑖𝒩\{{\cal OC}_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}} satisfying only (i) in Lemma 1. Should (ii) not hold for some i𝑖i, reset 𝒪​𝒞i:=⋃j∈𝒪i𝒪​𝒞i\𝒪​𝒞jassign𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖\𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{i}:=\bigcup_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}{\cal OC}_{i}\backslash{\cal OC}_{j}. With this modification, both (i) and (ii) in Lemma 1 hold and no extra color is needed. ∎

We have from Lemmas 4 and 5 that

Q​(χ​(𝒢))≤Q𝒢∗≤Q𝒢≤Q​(χ​(𝒢)).𝑄𝜒𝒢superscriptsubscript𝑄𝒢subscript𝑄𝒢𝑄𝜒𝒢Q(\chi({\cal G}))\leq Q_{{\cal G}}^{*}\leq Q_{{\cal G}}\leq Q(\chi({\cal G})).

Therefore, all inequalities must hold with equality.

Proposition 1

Let the chromatic number of graph 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} be χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}). Then, the solution of (1) is Q𝒢=Q​(χ​(𝒢))subscript𝑄𝒢𝑄𝜒𝒢Q_{{\cal G}}=Q(\chi({\cal G})), where the function Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot) is given by (3).

It is easy to see that Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot) is nondecreasing. The values of Q​(N)𝑄𝑁Q(N) for N=1,⋯,20𝑁1⋯20N=1,\cdots,20 are plotted in Figure 2.

For large N𝑁N, it follows from Stirling’s approximation [28]

(q⌊q/2⌋)=2π​exp⁡[q​ln⁡2−12​ln⁡q−14​q+o​(1q2)]binomial𝑞𝑞22𝜋𝑞212𝑞14𝑞𝑜1superscript𝑞2{{q}\choose{\lfloor{q/2}\rfloor}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\exp\left[q\ln 2-\frac{1}{2}\ln q-\frac{1}{4q}+o\left(\frac{1}{q^{2}}\right)\right]

that

Q​(N)=Θ​(log⁡N).𝑄𝑁Θ𝑁Q(N)=\Theta(\log N).

Therefore by Proposition 1, Q𝒢subscript𝑄𝒢Q_{\cal G} grows at a logarithmic rate with χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}).

IV Distributed Sub-band Allocation

IV-A Spectrum Division Using Approximation of χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G})

We have found that the minimum number of sub-bands depends on the chromatic number χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}). The problem of finding χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}), however, is NP-complete [26] in general. On the other hand, any upper bound on χ​(𝒢)𝜒𝒢\chi({\cal G}) gives us a sufficient number of sub-bands. One such well-known upper bound is χ​(𝒢)≤Δ​(𝒢)+1𝜒𝒢Δ𝒢1\chi({\cal G})\leq\Delta({\cal G})+1, where Δ​(𝒢)Δ𝒢\Delta({\cal G}) is the maximum degree of any node in 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. In the following, we assume that there are at least Q​(Δ​(𝒢)+1)𝑄Δ𝒢1Q(\Delta({\cal G})+1) sub-bands available.

The maximum degree Δ​(𝒢)Δ𝒢\Delta({\cal G}) is straightforward to determine (in a distributed manner), and we assume that it is known to all nodes a priori. Notice that Q​(Δ​(𝒢)+1)𝑄Δ𝒢1Q(\Delta({\cal G})+1) is not too far from Q​(χ​(𝒢))𝑄𝜒𝒢Q(\chi({\cal G})) in typical networks,777There are graphs, e.g. complete graphs, for which χ​(𝒢)≤Δ​(𝒢)+1𝜒𝒢Δ𝒢1\chi({\cal G})\leq\Delta({\cal G})+1 holds with equality. since the Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot) function is piecewise flat and grows approximately as a log function. It is worth comparing the upper bound Q​(Δ​(𝒢)+1)𝑄Δ𝒢1Q(\Delta({\cal G})+1) with Δ​(𝒢~)+1Δ~𝒢1\Delta(\tilde{\cal G})+1, an upper bound of χ​(𝒢~)𝜒~𝒢\chi(\tilde{\cal G}), the chromatic number of the interference graph. Recall that vertices of 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G} are (directed) links of 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. Any vertex (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) of 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G} has neighbors {(k,l)∈ℒ:k=j​or​l=i,but not both}conditional-set𝑘𝑙ℒformulae-sequence𝑘𝑗or𝑙𝑖but not both\{(k,l)\in{\cal L}:k=j~{}\textrm{or}~{}l=i,~{}\textrm{but not both}\}. Hence, by the assumption that 𝒢𝒢{\cal G} is link-symmetric, the degree of (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) in 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G} is given by

Δ(i,j)=|ℐi|+|𝒪j|−1=Δi+Δj−1.subscriptΔ𝑖𝑗subscriptℐ𝑖subscript𝒪𝑗1subscriptΔ𝑖subscriptΔ𝑗1\Delta_{(i,j)}=|{\cal I}_{i}|+|{\cal O}_{j}|-1=\Delta_{i}+\Delta_{j}-1.

Here, ΔisubscriptΔ𝑖\Delta_{i} and ΔjsubscriptΔ𝑗\Delta_{j} are the degrees of nodes i𝑖i and j𝑗j in 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}. Consequently, the maximum degree of 𝒢~~𝒢\tilde{\cal G} is

Δ​(𝒢~)=max(i,j)∈ℒ⁡Δi+Δj−1.Δ~𝒢subscript𝑖𝑗ℒsubscriptΔ𝑖subscriptΔ𝑗1\Delta(\tilde{\cal G})=\max_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}}\Delta_{i}+\Delta_{j}-1.

On the other hand, Δ​(𝒢)=maxi∈𝒩⁡ΔiΔ𝒢subscript𝑖𝒩subscriptΔ𝑖\Delta({\cal G})=\max_{i\in{\cal N}}\Delta_{i}. Therefore, it is always true that

Δ​(𝒢~)≥Δ​(𝒢).Δ~𝒢Δ𝒢\Delta(\tilde{\cal G})\geq\Delta({\cal G}).

The equality holds only when the network topology is extremely asymmetric, e.g. the star networks. Typically, Δ​(𝒢~)Δ~𝒢\Delta(\tilde{\cal G}) can be almost twice as large as Δ​(𝒢)Δ𝒢\Delta({\cal G}). Moreover, the Q​(⋅)𝑄⋅Q(\cdot) function is piecewise flat and scales as log2⁡(⋅)subscript2⋅\log_{2}(\cdot). The difference of the two upper bounds Δ​(𝒢~)+1−Q​(Δ​(𝒢)+1)Δ~𝒢1𝑄Δ𝒢1\Delta(\tilde{\cal G})+1-Q(\Delta({\cal G})+1) typically is substantial. Therefore, the connectivity graph approach developed in this work not only is more simple and straightforward but also leads to a tighter upper bound than the conventional interference graph approach.

IV-B Distributed Sub-band Allocation Algorithm

With the spectrum division accomplished, we now devise an algorithm with which feasible {𝒪​𝒞i}𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\{{\cal OC}_{i}\} can be determined in a distributed manner and a feasible spectrum allocation can be found. The algorithm applies to all connected and link-symmetric graphs. Assume that Q𝑄Q sub-bands are available. For expositional purposes, we keep an unprocessed node set 𝒰𝒰{\cal U}, which initially contains all the nodes. The Distributed Sub-band allocation (DSA) algorithm is iterated as follows.

Step 1. Initially 𝒰=𝒩𝒰𝒩{\cal U}={\cal N}. Arbitrarily select a node i𝑖i from 𝒰𝒰{\cal U} and set 𝒰:=𝒰\{i}assign𝒰\𝒰𝑖{\cal U}:={\cal U}\backslash\{i\}. Arbitrarily choose ⌊Q/2⌋𝑄2\lfloor Q/2\rfloor sub-bands to form 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i}, mark i𝑖i as “processed”, and go to Step 2.

Step 2. Select an arbitrary node i𝑖i from 𝒰𝒰{\cal U} such that i𝑖i has at least one processed neighbor (under the assumption that the network is connected, there is always such a node in 𝒰𝒰{\cal U} after the first node is processed) and set 𝒰:=𝒰\{i}assign𝒰\𝒰𝑖{\cal U}:={\cal U}\backslash\{i\}. Node i𝑖i finds an 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} with ⌊Q/2⌋𝑄2\lfloor Q/2\rfloor sub-bands which is different from all 𝒪​𝒞j𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{j} of its processed neighbors j𝑗j (it can be shown that such an 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} always exists). Moreover, to maximally avoid potential channel interference, i𝑖i selects sub-bands in increasing order of their number of occurrences888The number of occurrences can be zero. in {𝒪​𝒞j}j∈𝒪i\𝒰subscript𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗𝑗\subscript𝒪𝑖𝒰\{{\cal OC}_{j}\}_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}\backslash{\cal U}} (ties are broken arbitrarily).999For instance, if the whole set of sub-bands is {R,G,B,Y}𝑅𝐺𝐵𝑌\{R,G,B,Y\}, and node i𝑖i finds its two neighbors have chosen {R,G}𝑅𝐺\{R,G\} and {R,Y}𝑅𝑌\{R,Y\}, it will accordingly choose either {B,G}𝐵𝐺\{B,G\} or {B,Y}𝐵𝑌\{B,Y\}. Mark i𝑖i as “processed”. If 𝒰≠∅𝒰{\cal U}\neq\emptyset, repeat Step 2; otherwise go to Step 3.

Step 3. Each node i𝑖i allocates the sub-band(s) in 𝒬i​j:=𝒪​𝒞i\𝒪​𝒞jassignsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑗\𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal Q}_{ij}:={\cal OC}_{i}\backslash{\cal OC}_{j} to each outgoing link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j). The algorithm terminates.

Proposition 2

The set {𝒬i​j}(i,j)∈ℒsubscriptsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗ℒ\{{\cal Q}_{ij}\}_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}} generated by the DSA algorithm induces a feasible spectrum allocation {ℒq}q∈𝒬subscriptsubscriptℒ𝑞𝑞𝒬\{{\cal L}_{q}\}_{q\in{\cal Q}}.

Proof: First we show that in Step 2 of the algorithm, an appropriate 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} can always be found. Because the whole set has Q≥Q​(Δ​(𝒢)+1)𝑄𝑄Δ𝒢1Q\geq Q(\Delta({\cal G})+1) elements, there are at least Δ​(𝒢)+1Δ𝒢1\Delta({\cal G})+1 distinct subsets with cardinality ⌊Q/2⌋𝑄2\lfloor Q/2\rfloor. However, i𝑖i has at most Δ​(𝒢)Δ𝒢\Delta({\cal G}) (processed) neighbors. Hence, there always exists at least one candidate for 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i}.

Now we show that the {𝒪​𝒞i}𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\{{\cal OC}_{i}\} obtained up to Step 3 are feasible. They satisfy (i) in Lemma 1 due to the rule of successively selecting 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} in Step 2. They also satisfy (ii) in Lemma 1, as proved next. Suppose on the contrary that there exists i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N} and q∈𝒪​𝒞i𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖q\in{\cal OC}_{i} such that q∈𝒪​𝒞j𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗q\in{\cal OC}_{j} for all j∈𝒪i𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖j\in{\cal O}_{i}. If i𝑖i is not the first processed node, the fact that q∈𝒪​𝒞i𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖q\in{\cal OC}_{i} implies that by the time 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} is being determined, each of the Q−⌊Q/2⌋𝑄𝑄2Q-\lfloor Q/2\rfloor sub-bands not included in 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} must appear in every previously processed neighbor j𝑗j’s 𝒪​𝒞j𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{j}. Taking also q𝑞q into account, we can deduce that all those 𝒪​𝒞j𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{j} have at least ⌊Q/2⌋+1𝑄21\lfloor Q/2\rfloor+1 elements, which is a contradiction. Even if i𝑖i is the first processed node, the next processed node j𝑗j must be i𝑖i’s neighbor and 𝒪​𝒞j∪𝒪​𝒞i=∅𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{j}\cup{\cal OC}_{i}=\emptyset due to the algorithm’s rule. Hence, the hypothesis cannot be true in either case.

With the feasibility of the {𝒪​𝒞i}𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\{{\cal OC}_{i}\} established, it is easy to verify that the {𝒬i​j}(i,j)∈ℒsubscriptsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗ℒ\{{\cal Q}_{ij}\}_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}} generated in Step 3 induces a feasible spectrum allocation {ℒq}q∈𝒬subscriptsubscriptℒ𝑞𝑞𝒬\{{\cal L}_{q}\}_{q\in{\cal Q}}. ∎

In practice, the DSA algorithm can be implemented in a distributed fashion by nodes in the network. Specifically, after any node i𝑖i has arbitrarily set its 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} at the beginning, any other node j𝑗j can determine its own 𝒪​𝒞j𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗{\cal OC}_{j} as long as it has at least one processed neighbor and no other neighbor is being processed at the same instant. In other words, it is possible to have two non-adjacent nodes configuring their outgoing sub-bands at the same time. Since the action of a node depends only on its neighbors, node operations need not be globally coordinated or synchronized across the network. All that is required is an initialization phase that designates the first node to be processed. Thus, the sub-band allocation algorithm is distributed and asynchronous in nature.

Finally, we note that the DSA algorithm is robust to dynamic node failure and addition. Suppose that after a feasible spectrum allocation is established by the DSA algorithm, a node leaves the network. In this case, the configuration for the remaining nodes and links is still feasible. If a new node i𝑖i is to join the network, it can run Step 2 of the DSA algorithm to determine its own 𝒪​𝒞i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖{\cal OC}_{i} based on its neighbors’ 𝒪​𝒞j,j∈𝒪i𝒪subscript𝒞𝑗𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖{\cal OC}_{j},j\in{\cal O}_{i}. Then, active sub-bands for each link incident to i𝑖i can be allocated as in Step 3. As long as i𝑖i connects to at most Δ​(𝒢)Δ𝒢\Delta({\cal G}) nodes in the old network 𝒢𝒢{\cal G}, the algorithm yields a feasible spectrum allocation for node i𝑖i, with all other nodes’ allocation unaffected.

V Cross-layer Optimization in Multi-radio Multi-hop Wireless Networks

The algorithm in Section IV generates a spectrum allocation where the active links on every sub-band satisfy the duplexing constraints. Given this feasible spectrum allocation, we now develop corresponding joint power control, routing, and congestion control algorithms which minimize total network cost, which will be specified later, given channel conditions and traffic demands.

V-A Interference Limited Transmissions and Node Power Constraints

We consider networks where messages on each sub-band are coded independently, and where the receiver of a link decodes its message on an active sub-band while treating all other signals on the same sub-band as interference. We assume that the capacity Ci​j​(q)subscript𝐶𝑖𝑗𝑞C_{ij}(q) of link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) on a sub-band q𝑞q is a function of xi​j​(q)subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑞x_{ij}(q), the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) of link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) over q𝑞q. Denoting the transmission powers used by the active links on sub-band q𝑞q by {Pm​n​(q)}(m,n)∈ℒqsubscriptsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑛𝑞𝑚𝑛subscriptℒ𝑞\{P_{mn}(q)\}_{(m,n)\in{\cal L}_{q}}, we have

xi​j​(q)=Gi​jq​Pi​j​(q)∑(m,n)∈ℒq(m,n)≠(i,j)Gm​jq​Pm​n​(q)+Njq,subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑞superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝑚𝑛subscriptℒ𝑞𝑚𝑛𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑚𝑗𝑞subscript𝑃𝑚𝑛𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑞x_{ij}(q)=\frac{G_{ij}^{q}P_{ij}(q)}{\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}(m,n)\in{\cal L}_{q}\\ (m,n)\neq(i,j)\end{subarray}}G_{mj}^{q}P_{mn}(q)+N_{j}^{q}}, (4)

where Gm​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑚𝑗𝑞G_{mj}^{q} is the path gain from m𝑚m to j𝑗j on sub-band q𝑞q, and Njqsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑞N_{j}^{q} is the power of the additive noise on sub-band q𝑞q at j𝑗j. Note that since the parameters {Gi​jq}superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑗𝑞\{G_{ij}^{q}\} and {Njq}superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑗𝑞\{N_{j}^{q}\} are sub-band-dependent, this framework is particularly appropriate for networks with frequency selective channels and colored noise.

Assume each node is limited by an individual power constraint P¯isubscript¯𝑃𝑖\bar{P}_{i}, i.e.,

∑j∈𝒪i∑q∈𝒬i​jPi​j​(q)≤P¯i.subscript𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖subscript𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript¯𝑃𝑖\sum_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}\sum_{q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}P_{ij}(q)\leq\bar{P}_{i}. (5)

Denote the set of power variables {Pi​j​(q)}(i,j)∈ℒ,q∈𝒬i​jsubscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗𝑞formulae-sequence𝑖𝑗ℒ𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗\{P_{ij}(q)\}_{(i,j)\in{\cal L},q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}} that satisfy (5) by 𝒫𝒫{\cal P}. In Section VI, we will design a set of power control algorithms that adjusts the power variables within the feasible region to minimize total network cost in conjunction with congestion control and routing.

V-B Traffic Demands, Congestion Control, and Routing

Let the traffic demands for the network consist of a collection 𝒲𝒲{\cal W} of unicast sessions. Each (elastic) session w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\cal W} is characterized by its fixed source-destination node pair (O​(w),D​(w))𝑂𝑤𝐷𝑤(O(w),D(w)) and demand rate r¯wsubscript¯𝑟𝑤\bar{r}_{w}.101010We assume that user w𝑤w gains no extra utility by transmitting at a rate higher than r¯wsubscript¯𝑟𝑤\bar{r}_{w}. So without loss of optimality, r¯wsubscript¯𝑟𝑤\bar{r}_{w} can be taken as the effective maximal incoming rate demanded by w𝑤w. We model the traffic as fluid flows. Assume congestion control is exercised at each source node. That is the source node O​(w)𝑂𝑤O(w) can control the rate at which w𝑤w’s traffic comes into the network. Denote the actual admitted rate of w𝑤w by rwsubscript𝑟𝑤r_{w}, also referred to as the end-to-end flow rate of w𝑤w. Thus, the rate of the rejected traffic of w𝑤w, denoted by Fwsubscript𝐹𝑤F_{w}, is r¯w−rwsubscript¯𝑟𝑤subscript𝑟𝑤\bar{r}_{w}-r_{w}. After the admitted flow rates are determined by the congestion control at the source nodes, the flows entering the network are routed on (potentially) multiple paths from the source to destination. Let fi​j​(w)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤f_{ij}(w) denote the rate of session w𝑤w traffic routed through link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j). The session flows satisfy the flow conservation constraints, i.e.,

∑j∈𝒪ifi​j​(w)=rw,i=O​(w),formulae-sequencesubscript𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤subscript𝑟𝑤𝑖𝑂𝑤\sum_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}f_{ij}(w)=r_{w},\quad i=O(w), (6)
∑j∈𝒪ifi​j(w)=∑k∈𝒪ifk​i(w)=:ti(w),i≠O(w),D(w),\sum_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}f_{ij}(w)=\sum_{k\in{\cal O}_{i}}f_{ki}(w)=:t_{i}(w),\quad i\neq O(w),D(w), (7)

and

fi​j​(w)=0,∀j∈𝒪i,i=D​(w).formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤0formulae-sequencefor-all𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖𝑖𝐷𝑤f_{ij}(w)=0,\quad\forall j\in{\cal O}_{i},\quad i=D(w). (8)

Here, ti​(w)subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤t_{i}(w) denotes both the total incoming and outgoing flow rates of session w𝑤w at an intermediate node i𝑖i. If we consider the rejected flow Fwsubscript𝐹𝑤F_{w} as being routed on a virtual “overflow” link from O​(w)𝑂𝑤O(w) to D​(w)𝐷𝑤D(w) [29, 30], the flow conservation constraint involving both real and virtual outgoing flows from the source node is given by

∑j∈𝒪ifi​j​(w)+Fw=r¯w.subscript𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤subscript𝐹𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤\sum_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}f_{ij}(w)+F_{w}=\bar{r}_{w}. (9)

Thus, later on we will incorporate congestion control in a unified framework with routing. Let the set of flow vectors (Fw,(fi​j​(w))(i,j)∈ℒ)subscript𝐹𝑤subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤𝑖𝑗ℒ(F_{w},(f_{ij}(w))_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}}) satisfying (7)-(9) be denoted by ℱwsubscriptℱ𝑤{\cal F}_{w}.

The total flow rate on link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) is Fi​j=∑w∈𝒲fi​j​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗subscript𝑤𝒲subscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤F_{ij}=\sum_{w\in{\cal W}}f_{ij}(w). To route a flow of rate Fi​jsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑗F_{ij} from i𝑖i to j𝑗j, node i𝑖i can split the traffic onto all active sub-bands of link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) and transmit them simultaneously. Let the rate of flow assigned to sub-band q∈𝒬i​j𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗q\in{\cal Q}_{ij} be Fi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}(q). We have Fi​j=∑q∈𝒬i​jFi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗subscript𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}=\sum_{q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}F_{ij}(q). Hence,

∑q∈𝒬i​jFi​j​(q)=∑w∈𝒲fi​j​(w).subscript𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝑤𝒲subscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤\sum_{q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}F_{ij}(q)=\sum_{w\in{\cal W}}f_{ij}(w). (10)

Note that the flow on each sub-band may consist of traffic of one or more sessions. However, the traffic split conserves the total rate of any session going through link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j). Therefore, at the receiver end of the link, node j𝑗j collects each session w𝑤w’s traffic of rate fi​j​(w)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤f_{ij}(w).

One can think of the routing scheme as a two-step process. The first step determines inter-node routing, i.e., a feasible flow vector (Fw,(fi​j​(w))(i,j)∈ℒ)∈ℱwsubscript𝐹𝑤subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤𝑖𝑗ℒsubscriptℱ𝑤(F_{w},(f_{ij}(w))_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}})\in{\cal F}_{w} is found for every w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\cal W}, yielding (Fi​j)(i,j)∈ℒsubscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗ℒ(F_{ij})_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}}. The second step amounts to intra-node routing: each node i𝑖i routes the flow Fi​jsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑗F_{ij} onto the active sub-bands q∈𝒬i​j𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗q\in{\cal Q}_{ij} available from i𝑖i to j𝑗j.

V-C Network Cost and Optimal Resource Allocation

The cost on each (real) link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) is made up of the costs Di​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q} incurred on its active sub-band(s) q∈𝒬i​j𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}. Each Di​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q} is a function of xi​j​(q)subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑞x_{ij}(q), the SINR of link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) on q𝑞q, and Fi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}(q), the flow rate on the active sub-band q𝑞q of link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j). Specifically, define

Di​jq=D​(xi​j​(q),Fi​j​(q)).superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞𝐷subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q}=D(x_{ij}(q),F_{ij}(q)).

Assume that D​(x,F)𝐷𝑥𝐹D(x,F) is decreasing and convex in x𝑥x for fixed F𝐹F, and that it is increasing and convex in F𝐹F for fixed x𝑥x. To impose the hard capacity constraint F<C​(x)𝐹𝐶𝑥F<C(x), where C​(x)𝐶𝑥C(x) denotes the link capacity achieved by having S​I​N​R=x𝑆𝐼𝑁𝑅𝑥SINR=x, one can define D​(x,F)=∞𝐷𝑥𝐹D(x,F)=\infty for F≥C​(x)𝐹𝐶𝑥F\geq C(x). An example of such cost functions is111111For modelling purposes, we assume that on the transmitter side of each link there is one queue for every active sub-band of that link. Specifically, the arrival rate to the queue of link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) on sub-band q𝑞q is Fi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}(q), the aggregate flow routed onto (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) through q𝑞q. The cost function D​(x,F)=FC​(x)−F𝐷𝑥𝐹𝐹𝐶𝑥𝐹D(x,F)=\frac{F}{C(x)-F} gives the expected delay in an M/M/1 queue with arrival rate F𝐹F and service capacity C​(x)𝐶𝑥C(x). In our present setting, F𝐹F is the sub-band specific link flow rate and C​(x)𝐶𝑥C(x) is the sub-band specific link capacity. By the Kleinrock independence approximation and Jackson’s Theorem, the M/M/1𝑀𝑀1M/M/1 queue is a good approximation for the behavior of individual links on active sub-bands when the system involves Poisson stream arrivals at the entry points, a densely connected network, and moderate-to-heavy traffic load [31, 29]. D​(x,F)=FC​(x)−F𝐷𝑥𝐹𝐹𝐶𝑥𝐹D(x,F)=\frac{F}{C(x)-F} where C​(x)=R​log⁡(K​x)𝐶𝑥𝑅𝐾𝑥C(x)=R\log(Kx) with constants R,K>0𝑅𝐾0R,K>0.121212The constants R,K𝑅𝐾R,K correspond to the bandwidth and processing gain of the system. The capacity formula C​(x)=R​log⁡(K​x)𝐶𝑥𝑅𝐾𝑥C(x)=R\log(Kx) is a good approximation for systems with a high processing gain, e.g. CDMA networks.

We associate an increasing and concave utility function Uw​(rw)subscript𝑈𝑤subscript𝑟𝑤U_{w}(r_{w}), 0≤rw≤r¯w0subscript𝑟𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤0\leq r_{w}\leq\bar{r}_{w}, to each (elastic) session w𝑤w. Thus, rejecting a flow of Fwsubscript𝐹𝑤F_{w} from the network incurs a utility loss of Uw​(r¯w)−Uw​(r¯w−Fw)subscript𝑈𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤subscript𝑈𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤subscript𝐹𝑤U_{w}(\bar{r}_{w})-U_{w}(\bar{r}_{w}-F_{w}). This utility loss can also be interpreted as the cost Dw​(Fw)≜Uw​(r¯w)−Uw​(r¯w−Fw)≜subscript𝐷𝑤subscript𝐹𝑤subscript𝑈𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤subscript𝑈𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤subscript𝐹𝑤D_{w}(F_{w})\triangleq U_{w}(\bar{r}_{w})-U_{w}(\bar{r}_{w}-F_{w}) on a virtual overflow link [29] with flow rate Fwsubscript𝐹𝑤F_{w}. Note that by definition, Dw​(Fw)subscript𝐷𝑤subscript𝐹𝑤D_{w}(F_{w}) is increasing and convex in Fwsubscript𝐹𝑤F_{w}.

We solve for the feasible flow and power variables that jointly maximize the net utility, i.e., total utility minus total cost on real links. With the above observation, the maximization of net utility is equivalent to the problem of minimizing the total network cost E≜∑(i,j)∈ℒDi​j+∑w∈𝒲Dw≜𝐸subscript𝑖𝑗ℒsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗subscript𝑤𝒲subscript𝐷𝑤E\triangleq\sum_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}}D_{ij}+\sum_{w\in{\cal W}}D_{w} consisting of costs on both real and overflow links. Formally, the Multi-Radio Minimum Cost Resource Allocation (MCRA) problem is

minimize ∑w∈𝒲Dw​(Fw)+∑(i,j)∈ℒ∑q∈𝒬i​jD​(xi​j​(q),Fi​j​(q))subscript𝑤𝒲subscript𝐷𝑤subscript𝐹𝑤subscript𝑖𝑗ℒsubscript𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗𝐷subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞\displaystyle\sum_{w\in{\cal W}}D_{w}(F_{w})+\sum_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}}\sum_{q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}D(x_{ij}(q),F_{ij}(q))
subject to (​4​)​and​(Pi​j​(q))(i,j)∈ℒ,q∈𝒬i​j∈𝒫,italic-(4italic-)andsubscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑗𝑞formulae-sequence𝑖𝑗ℒ𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗𝒫\displaystyle\eqref{eq:SINR}~{}\textrm{and}~{}(P_{ij}(q))_{(i,j)\in{\cal L},q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}\in{\cal P},
(​10​)​and​(Fw,(fi​j​(w))(i,j)∈ℒ)∈ℱw,∀w∈𝒲.formulae-sequenceitalic-(10italic-)andsubscript𝐹𝑤subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤𝑖𝑗ℒsubscriptℱ𝑤for-all𝑤𝒲\displaystyle\eqref{eq:FlowEquation}~{}\textrm{and}~{}(F_{w},(f_{ij}(w))_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}})\in{\cal F}_{w},\;\forall w\in{\cal W}.

We will devise a distributed scheme that iteratively adjusts power control, routing and congestion control on a node-by-node basis so as to find the optimal solution to the MCRA problem.

V-D Control Variables and Optimality Conditions

To update transmission powers, traffic routes, and traffic input rates, we define the following power control and routing variables. These optimization variables are node-based and local in the sense that they are independently controlled at individual nodes.

V-D1 Power Control Variables

Let Pi​(q)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑞P_{i}(q) be the total power used by node i𝑖i on its active sub-band q𝑞q. Let Pi​j​(q)subscript𝑃𝑖𝑗𝑞P_{ij}(q) be the power used by node i𝑖i on its outgoing link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) over an active sub-band q𝑞q. Define

ρi​(q)≜Pi​(q)P¯i,q∈𝒪​𝒞i,formulae-sequence≜subscript𝜌𝑖𝑞subscript𝑃𝑖𝑞subscript¯𝑃𝑖𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\rho_{i}(q)\triangleq\frac{P_{i}(q)}{\bar{P}_{i}},\quad q\in{\cal OC}_{i},

constrained by

0≤ρi​(q)≤1,∑q∈𝒪​𝒞iρi​(q)≤1.formulae-sequence0subscript𝜌𝑖𝑞1subscript𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖𝑞1\quad 0\leq\rho_{i}(q)\leq 1,\quad\sum_{q\in{\cal OC}_{i}}\rho_{i}(q)\leq 1. (11)

Also define

(13)

We use I​Ni​j​(q)𝐼subscript𝑁𝑖𝑗𝑞IN_{ij}(q) to denote the total interference and noise power of link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) on sub-band q𝑞q, i.e. the denominator of (13).

Define 𝝆i≜(ρi​(q))q∈𝒪​𝒞i≜subscript𝝆𝑖subscriptsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑞𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i}\triangleq(\rho_{i}(q))_{q\in{\cal OC}_{i}} and 𝜼i≜(ηi​j​(q))j∈𝒪i,q∈𝒬i​j≜subscript𝜼𝑖subscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖𝑗𝑞formulae-sequence𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}\triangleq(\eta_{ij}(q))_{j\in{\cal O}_{i},q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}. on all its active incoming links (m,n)𝑚𝑛(m,n) on q𝑞q, and summing them up (cf. (17)). Note that M​S​Gnq𝑀𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑞MSG_{n}^{q} is nonnegative and it is zero if n𝑛n has no active incoming link on q𝑞q. If M​S​Gnq>0𝑀𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑞0MSG_{n}^{q}>0, node n𝑛n broadcasts it to the whole network via a flooding protocol. This control message generating process is illustrated by Figure 3.

If q∈𝒪​𝒞i𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖q\in{\cal OC}_{i}, node i𝑖i collects M​S​Gnq𝑀𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑞MSG_{n}^{q} and processes it according to the following rule. Node i𝑖i multiplies M​S​Gnq𝑀𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑞MSG_{n}^{q} with the path gain Gi​nqsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑛𝑞G_{in}^{q}.131313In a symmetric duplex channel, Gi​nq≈Gn​iqsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑛𝑞superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖𝑞G_{in}^{q}\approx G_{ni}^{q}, and node i𝑖i may use its own measurement of Gn​iqsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑖𝑞G_{ni}^{q} in the place of Gi​nqsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑛𝑞G_{in}^{q}. Otherwise, it will need channel feedback from node n𝑛n to calculate Gi​nqsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑛𝑞G_{in}^{q}. It further adds the product to the value of local measure δ​ηi​n​(q)⋅ηi​n​(q)⋅𝛿subscript𝜂𝑖𝑛𝑞subscript𝜂𝑖𝑛𝑞\delta\eta_{in}(q)\cdot\eta_{in}(q) if the origin n𝑛n of the message is a neighbor of i𝑖i and (i,n)𝑖𝑛(i,n) is active on sub-band q𝑞q. Finally, node i𝑖i adds up all the processed messages, and this sum multiplied by P¯isubscript¯𝑃𝑖\bar{P}_{i} equals δ​ρi​(q)𝛿subscript𝜌𝑖𝑞\delta\rho_{i}(q). Note that this protocol requires only one message from each node on each sub-band q𝑞q.141414To be more precise, only the nodes having at least one active incoming link on a certain sub-band need to provide a message for that sub-band. Moreover in practice, node i𝑖i can ignore the messages generated by distant nodes, because they contribute very little to δ​ρi​(q)𝛿subscript𝜌𝑖𝑞\delta\rho_{i}(q) due to the negligible multiplicative factor Gi​nqsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑛𝑞G_{in}^{q} on M​S​Gnq𝑀𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑞MSG_{n}^{q} when i𝑖i and n𝑛n are far apart (cf. (16)).

V-D2 Routing Variables

Routing variables were first introduced by Gallager [32] for wireline network routing problems. Here, we define routing variables in a similar fashion. In addition to inter-node routing, however, routing variables here also perform the function of congestion control and intra-node routing.

Recall that congestion control is equivalent to routing a portion of traffic demand on a virtual overflow link directly from the source to the destination. Let i𝑖i be the source node of session w𝑤w, define overflow routing variable

ϕw≜Fwr¯w,≜subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤subscript𝐹𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤\phi_{w}\triangleq\frac{F_{w}}{\bar{r}_{w}},

which is constrained by 0≤ϕw≤10subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤10\leq\phi_{w}\leq 1. The overflow rate is then controlled by ϕwsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤\phi_{w} as Fw=r¯w​ϕwsubscript𝐹𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤F_{w}=\bar{r}_{w}\phi_{w}, and the end-to-end flow rate is given by rw=r¯w​(1−ϕw)subscript𝑟𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤1subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤r_{w}=\bar{r}_{w}(1-\phi_{w}). Routing variables associated with a real link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) are defined by

ϕi​j​(w)≜fi​j​(w)ti​(w),≜subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤\phi_{ij}(w)\triangleq\frac{f_{ij}(w)}{t_{i}(w)},

which gives the fraction of the incoming flow of session w𝑤w at node i𝑖i that is routed onto link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j). At any node i𝑖i except the destination, ϕi​j​(w)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤\phi_{ij}(w) of all j∈𝒪i𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖j\in{\cal O}_{i} satisfy

0≤ϕi​j​(w)≤1and∑j∈𝒪iϕi​j​(w)=1.formulae-sequence0subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤1andsubscript𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤10\leq\phi_{ij}(w)\leq 1\quad\textrm{and}\quad\sum_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}\phi_{ij}(w)=1. (18)

It is easy to see that the routing variables ϕw,ϕi​j​(w)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤\phi_{w},\phi_{ij}(w) of all (i,j)∈ℒ𝑖𝑗ℒ(i,j)\in{\cal L} and w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\cal W} uniquely determine the inter-node flow patterns (Fw,(fi​j​(w))(i,j)∈ℒ)subscript𝐹𝑤subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤𝑖𝑗ℒ(F_{w},(f_{ij}(w))_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}}) of all sessions w𝑤w, and hence the total flow rate on links Fi​j=∑wfi​j​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗subscript𝑤subscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑤F_{ij}=\sum_{w}f_{ij}(w). Now let the flow allocation on active sub-bands be specified by the intra-node routing variables defined by

μi​j​(q)≜Fi​j​(q)Fi​j,q∈𝒬i​j.formulae-sequence≜subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗\mu_{ij}(q)\triangleq\frac{F_{ij}(q)}{F_{ij}},\quad q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}.

For any link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j), we must have

0≤μi​j​(q)≤1and∑q∈𝒬i​jμi​j​(q)=1.formulae-sequence0subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞1andsubscript𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞10\leq\mu_{ij}(q)\leq 1\quad\textrm{and}\quad\sum_{q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}\mu_{ij}(q)=1. (19)

The link flow rate on an active sub-band is therefore given by

Fi​j​(q)=μi​j​(q)​∑w∈𝒲ti​(w)​ϕi​j​(w),q∈𝒬i​j.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝑤𝒲subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗F_{ij}(q)=\mu_{ij}(q)\sum_{w\in{\cal W}}t_{i}(w)\phi_{ij}(w),\quad q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}.

For notational brevity, denote by ϕi​(w)subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝑤\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(w) the vector (ϕi​j​(w))j∈𝒪isubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖(\phi_{ij}(w))_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}} if i≠O​(w),D​(w)𝑖𝑂𝑤𝐷𝑤i\neq O(w),D(w), or (ϕw,(ϕi​j​(w))j∈𝒪i)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖(\phi_{w},(\phi_{ij}(w))_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}) if i=O​(w)𝑖𝑂𝑤i=O(w). Also denote by 𝝁isubscript𝝁𝑖\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i} the vector (μi​j​(q))j∈𝒪i,q∈𝒬i​jsubscriptsubscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞formulae-sequence𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗(\mu_{ij}(q))_{j\in{\cal O}_{i},q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}. We illustrate the use of the above routing variables by looking at a source node i𝑖i and one of its outgoing links (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) in Figures 4 and 5. In Figure 4, the overflow link is marked by a solid line with hollow arrow.

In Figure 5, we assume that link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) is active on two sub-bands q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2}, and that the inter-node flow rate from i𝑖i to j𝑗j is Fi​jsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑗F_{ij}.

We now compute the partial derivative of E𝐸E with respect to those routing variables. First we have the derivative of E𝐸E with respect to the overflow routing variables

∂E∂ϕw=r¯w​(Dw′−∂E∂tw),𝐸subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤subscript¯𝑟𝑤superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑤′𝐸subscript𝑡𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial\phi_{w}}=\bar{r}_{w}\left(D_{w}^{\prime}-\frac{\partial E}{\partial t_{w}}\right),

where ∂E∂tw𝐸subscript𝑡𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial t_{w}} is the marginal cost of increasing the end-to-end flow rate of session w𝑤w with all other variables held constant. This is a special case (i=O​(w)𝑖𝑂𝑤i=O(w)) of ∂E∂ti​(w)𝐸subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial t_{i}(w)}, which is the marginal cost of increasing the incoming flow rate of w𝑤w at node i𝑖i while keeping all other variables constant. These marginal costs are computed recursively as in [32]:

∂E∂ti​(w)=0,if ​i=D​(w),formulae-sequence𝐸subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤0if 𝑖𝐷𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial t_{i}(w)}=0,\quad\textrm{if~{}}i=D(w),

and for i≠D​(w)𝑖𝐷𝑤i\neq D(w),

∂E∂ti​(w)𝐸subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤\displaystyle\frac{\partial E}{\partial t_{i}(w)} =\displaystyle= ∑j∈𝒪iϕi​j​(w)​(∑q∈𝒬i​jμi​j​(q)​DFi​jq′+∂E∂tj​(w))subscript𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤subscript𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐷subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞′𝐸subscript𝑡𝑗𝑤\displaystyle\sum_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}\phi_{ij}(w)\left(\sum_{q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}}\mu_{ij}(q){D_{F_{ij}}^{q}}^{\prime}+\frac{\partial E}{\partial t_{j}(w)}\right) (20)
=\displaystyle= ∑j∈𝒪iϕi​j​(w)​δ​ϕi​j​(w),subscript𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤𝛿subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤\displaystyle\sum_{j\in{\cal O}_{i}}\phi_{ij}(w)\delta\phi_{ij}(w),

where we have used shorthand notation DFi​jq′superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐷subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞′{D_{F_{ij}}^{q}}^{\prime} for ∂D​(xi​j​(q),Fi​j​(q))/∂Fi​j​(q)𝐷subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞\partial D(x_{ij}(q),F_{ij}(q))/\partial F_{ij}(q) and defined marginal routing cost indicators

Using δ​ϕi​j​(w)𝛿subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤\delta\phi_{ij}(w), we can easily write out the partial derivative of E𝐸E in ϕi​j​(w)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤\phi_{ij}(w) as

∂E∂ϕi​j​(w)=ti​(w)​δ​ϕi​j​(w).𝐸subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤𝛿subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial\phi_{ij}(w)}=t_{i}(w)\delta\phi_{ij}(w). (22)

Finally, the partial derivative of E𝐸E in μi​j​(q)subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞\mu_{ij}(q) is given by

∂E∂μi​j​(q)=Fi​j​DFi​jq′.𝐸subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐷subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞′\frac{\partial E}{\partial\mu_{ij}(q)}=F_{ij}{D_{F_{ij}}^{q}}^{\prime}. (23)

Notice that ∂E∂μi​j​(q)𝐸subscript𝜇𝑖𝑗𝑞\frac{\partial E}{\partial\mu_{ij}(q)} depends on local measures only. However, ∂E∂ϕw𝐸subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial\phi_{w}} and ∂E∂ϕi​j​(w)𝐸subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial\phi_{ij}(w)} are both tied to the value of ∂E∂tj​(w)𝐸subscript𝑡𝑗𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial t_{j}(w)} of i𝑖i’s downstream151515Given a routing configuration {ϕi​j​(w)}(i,j)∈ℒsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤𝑖𝑗ℒ\{\phi_{ij}(w)\}_{(i,j)\in{\cal L}} of session w𝑤w, node j𝑗j is said to be downstream to i𝑖i if there exists a path (i,j1)𝑖subscript𝑗1(i,j_{1}), (j1,j2)subscript𝑗1subscript𝑗2(j_{1},j_{2}), ⋯⋯\cdots, (jn,j)subscript𝑗𝑛𝑗(j_{n},j) such that ϕi​j1subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑗1\phi_{ij_{1}}, ϕj1​j2subscriptitalic-ϕsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑗2\phi_{j_{1}j_{2}}, ⋯⋯\cdots, ϕjn​jsubscriptitalic-ϕsubscript𝑗𝑛𝑗\phi_{j_{n}j} are all positive. We say i𝑖i is upstream to j𝑗j with respect to session w𝑤w if j𝑗j is downstream to i𝑖i. neighbors j𝑗j, which in turn depends on ∂E∂tk​(w)𝐸subscript𝑡𝑘𝑤\frac{\partial E}{\partial t_{k}(w)} of j𝑗j’s downstream neighbors k𝑘k. Thus, we need a sequential message passing of the marginal routing costs, from the destination upstream to the source, to permit every node to acquire the partial derivatives in its local routing variables.

Routing Message Exchange Protocol: In [32], the rules for propagating the marginal routing cost information are specified. In order for node i𝑖i to evaluate the terms δ​ϕi​j​(w)𝛿subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑗𝑤\delta\phi_{ij}(w) in (21), it needs to collect local measures DFi​jq′superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐷subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞′{D_{F_{ij}}^{q}}^{\prime} from all q∈𝒬i​j𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗q\in{\cal Q}_{ij} as well as reports of marginal costs ∂D/∂rj​(w)𝐷subscript𝑟𝑗𝑤{\partial D}/{\partial r_{j}(w)} from its next-hop neighbors j∈𝒪i𝑗subscript𝒪𝑖j\in{\cal O}_{i}, for all traversing sessions w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\cal W}. Moreover, it is responsible for calculating its own measure of marginal cost ∂D∂ti​(w)𝐷subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤\frac{\partial D}{\partial t_{i}(w)} with respect to every session w𝑤w according to (20), and then providing the measure to its upstream neighbors with respect to the session w𝑤w. The sequential message passing terminates if and only if the routing pattern of the session contains no loops, which is guaranteed by the blocked-node-set technique developed in [32, 33].

V-D3 Conditions for Optimality

The power and routing configuration that solves the MCRA problem can be characterized in terms of the marginal power and routing costs as follows.

Theorem 1

For an instance of optimization variables {𝛒i,𝛈i,{ϕi​(w)}w∈𝒲,𝛍i}i∈𝒩subscriptsubscript𝛒𝑖subscript𝛈𝑖subscriptsubscriptbold-ϕ𝑖𝑤𝑤𝒲subscript𝛍𝑖𝑖𝒩\{\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i},\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i},\{\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(w)\}_{w\in{\cal W}},\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}} to be optimal, the following conditions are necessary: For all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N} and w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\cal W} with ti​(w)>0subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤0t_{i}(w)>0,

(24)

We sketch the proof of Theorem 1 in Appendix -C. First order conditions as in (24)-(28) are in general only necessary for a configuration to be optimal. However, they are further sufficient if the link cost function D​(x,F)𝐷𝑥𝐹D(x,F) has certain convexity properties as we discuss next.

Let x𝑥x generically represent the SINR of a link on one of its active sub-bands. By (4), x𝑥x is a function of the power variables of all active links on the same sub-band, e.g. xi​j​(q)=hi​jq​((Pm​n​(q))(m,n)∈ℒq)subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑞superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑞subscriptsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑛𝑞𝑚𝑛subscriptℒ𝑞x_{ij}(q)=h_{ij}^{q}((P_{mn}(q))_{(m,n)\in{\cal L}_{q}}). Thus, Di​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q} is a function of the vector 𝑷​(q)≜(Pm​n​(q))(m,n)∈ℒq≜𝑷𝑞subscriptsubscript𝑃𝑚𝑛𝑞𝑚𝑛subscriptℒ𝑞\boldsymbol{P}(q)\triangleq(P_{mn}(q))_{(m,n)\in{\cal L}_{q}} and Fi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}(q). It turns out that a characterization of the sufficient conditions for optimality requires Di​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q} to be jointly convex in 𝑷​(q)𝑷𝑞\boldsymbol{P}(q) and Fi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}(q). However, it can be shown that such a property is impossible given the assumption that Di​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q} is decreasing in xi​j​(q)subscript𝑥𝑖𝑗𝑞x_{ij}(q).

One way to remedy this problem is to work with log-power variables, first introduced in [1, 2]. For each (m,n)∈ℒ𝑚𝑛ℒ(m,n)\in{\cal L} and q∈𝒬m​n𝑞subscript𝒬𝑚𝑛q\in{\cal Q}_{mn}, define Sm​n​(q)=ln⁡Pm​n​(q)subscript𝑆𝑚𝑛𝑞subscript𝑃𝑚𝑛𝑞S_{mn}(q)=\ln P_{mn}(q). Consider Di​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q} as a function of 𝑺​(q)≜(Sm​n​(q))(m,n)∈ℒq≜𝑺𝑞subscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚𝑛𝑞𝑚𝑛subscriptℒ𝑞\boldsymbol{S}(q)\triangleq(S_{mn}(q))_{(m,n)\in{\cal L}_{q}} and Fi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}(q). If Di​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q} is jointly convex in 𝑺​(q)𝑺𝑞\boldsymbol{S}(q) and Fi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}(q), the conditions in Theorem 1 are enough to imply the optimality of a configuration. The joint convexity property holds if and only if the link cost function D​(x,F)𝐷𝑥𝐹D(x,F) satisfies the following.

Lemma 6

For all (i,j)∈ℒ𝑖𝑗ℒ(i,j)\in{\cal L} and q∈𝒬i​j𝑞subscript𝒬𝑖𝑗q\in{\cal Q}_{ij}, Di​jqsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑖𝑗𝑞D_{ij}^{q} is jointly convex in 𝐒​(q)𝐒𝑞\boldsymbol{S}(q) and Fi​j​(q)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑗𝑞F_{ij}(q) if and only if the matrix

is positive semidefinite for all (x,F)𝑥𝐹(x,F).

Limited by the available space, we skip the proof of Lemma 6. We prove in Appendix -D that if the condition in Lemma 6 holds, the conditions stated in the next theorem are sufficient for optimality.

Theorem 2

If the matrix M𝑀M in (29) of link cost function D​(x,F)𝐷𝑥𝐹D(x,F) is positive semidefinite, then conditions (24)-(28) are sufficient for {𝛒i,𝛈i,{ϕi​(w)}w∈𝒲,𝛍i}i∈𝒩subscriptsubscript𝛒𝑖subscript𝛈𝑖subscriptsubscriptbold-ϕ𝑖𝑤𝑤𝒲subscript𝛍𝑖𝑖𝒩\{\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i},\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i},\{\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(w)\}_{w\in{\cal W}},\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}} to be optimal if (24) holds at every node i≠D​(w)𝑖𝐷𝑤i\neq D(w) whether ti​(w)>0subscript𝑡𝑖𝑤0t_{i}(w)>0 or not, and if (28) holds for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N} and q∈𝒪​𝒞i𝑞𝒪subscript𝒞𝑖q\in{\cal OC}_{i} whether ρi​(q)>0subscript𝜌𝑖𝑞0\rho_{i}(q)>0 or not.

VI Node-Based Multi-Radio Power Control and Routing Algorithms

We develop a set of scaled gradient projection algorithms [34] by which individual nodes adjust their local power control and routing variables iteratively to achieve a global configuration satisfying the optimality conditions in Theorem 2. Each algorithm at a node updates the appropriate vector of local optimization variables, e.g. 𝝆isubscript𝝆𝑖\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i}, 𝜼isubscript𝜼𝑖\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}, ϕi​(w)subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑖𝑤\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(w) or 𝝁isubscript𝝁𝑖\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}, such that the updated vector results in a lower cost with all other variables held constant. This is achieved by updating the old vector in the opposite gradient direction scaled by an appropriate positive definite matrix, and projecting the new vector back into the feasible set whenever it falls outside. This technique has been applied to, for example, optimal routing in wireline networks [33] and optimal power control and routing in single-radio wireless networks [3].

VI-C Convergence of Algorithms

Having described the node-based power control and routing algorithms, we now state the main convergence result in the following theorem.

Theorem 3

Given a feasible spectrum allocation {ℒq}q∈𝒬subscriptsubscriptℒ𝑞𝑞𝒬\{{\cal L}_{q}\}_{q\in{\cal Q}}, let {𝛈i0}superscriptsubscript𝛈𝑖0\{\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}^{0}\}, {𝛒i0}superscriptsubscript𝛒𝑖0\{\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i}^{0}\}, {ϕi​(w)}subscriptbold-ϕ𝑖𝑤\{\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}(w)\}, {𝛍i}subscript𝛍𝑖\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}\} be any feasible initial transmission power and routing configuration with finite cost. Then with appropriate scaling matrices, the update sequences {𝛈ik}k=1∞superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛈𝑖𝑘𝑘1\{\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}^{k}\}_{k=1}^{\infty}, {𝛒ik}k=1∞superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛒𝑖𝑘𝑘1\{\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i}^{k}\}_{k=1}^{\infty}, {ϕik​(w)}k=1∞superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptbold-ϕ𝑖𝑘𝑤𝑘1\{\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{k}(w)\}_{k=1}^{\infty} and {𝛍ik}k=1∞superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛍𝑖𝑘𝑘1\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}^{k}\}_{k=1}^{\infty} generated by the algorithms (30), (31), (32) and (34) converge, i.e., 𝛈ik→𝛈i∗→superscriptsubscript𝛈𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛈𝑖\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}^{k}\to\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}^{*}, 𝛒ik→𝛒i∗→superscriptsubscript𝛒𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛒𝑖\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i}^{k}\to\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i}^{*}, ϕik​(w)→ϕi∗​(w)→superscriptsubscriptbold-ϕ𝑖𝑘𝑤superscriptsubscriptbold-ϕ𝑖𝑤\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{k}(w)\to\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{*}(w), and 𝛍ik→𝛍i∗→superscriptsubscript𝛍𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛍𝑖\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}^{k}\to\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}^{*} for all i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in{\cal N} and w∈𝒲𝑤𝒲w\in{\cal W} as k→∞→𝑘k\to\infty. Furthermore, the limiting configuration {𝛈i∗}superscriptsubscript𝛈𝑖\{\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}^{*}\}, {𝛒i∗}superscriptsubscript𝛒𝑖\{\boldsymbol{\rho}_{i}^{*}\}, {ϕi∗​(w)}superscriptsubscriptbold-ϕ𝑖𝑤\{\boldsymbol{\phi}_{i}^{*}(w)\}, {𝛍i∗}superscriptsubscript𝛍𝑖\{\boldsymbol{\mu}_{i}^{*}\} satisfies the conditions in Theorem 2, and is a jointly optimal solution to the MCRA problem if the link cost function D​(x,F)𝐷𝑥𝐹D(x,F) satisfies the condition in Lemma 6.

The proof hinges on the fact that, by using appropriate scaling matrices, every iteration of the algorithms (30), (31), (31) and (32) reduces the total cost of the MCRA problem until the optimality conditions in Theorem 2 are achieved. Finding the appropriate scaling matrices, however, is a major challenge. One approach to this problem is to choose the scaling matrices so that they upper bound the Hessian matrices with respect to the updated variables. In this way, the algorithms closely approximate Newton’s method, hence enjoying fast rate of convergence while simultaneously guaranteeing convergence from all initial conditions. This method has been successfully adopted in the power control and routing algorithms for single-radio wireless networks in [3], and can be generalized to the present context. Due to the limited space, however, we skip the details.

It is worth noting that convergence does not depend on any particular order of running the algorithms at different nodes. At any time, any node can update any set of its local optimization variables via the corresponding algorithm. All that is required for convergence is that each node iterates every algorithm until the adjusted variables have marginal costs satisfying conditions in Theorem 2. Finally, we note that convergence occurs from any initial configuration with finite cost. These features are crucial to the applicability of these algorithms to large networks which lack the ability of scheduling and synchronizing node operations.

Extensive simulations indicate that our algorithms are adaptive to time-varying network state, including channel fading, network topology, and traffic demand. Because every iteration of any algorithm always reduces the total cost under the current network condition, our scheme is able to constantly readjust routing and transmission powers towards the optimum that slowly shifts over time due to the network change.

VII Conclusion

We have developed an integrated cross-layer resource allocation scheme for general wireless multi-hop networks. To satisfy the fundamental duplexing constraints, our scheme first finds a feasible spectrum allocation by (1) dividing the whole spectrum into multiple sub-bands and (2) activating conflict-free links on each sub-band. Compared with traditional scheduling in time, the spectrum allocation technique has a number of advantages in operational simplicity and amenability to distributed and asynchronous implementation. By studying an equivalent combinatorial link-coloring problem, we found that the minimum number of sub-bands required by a feasible spectrum allocation is given by a simple function of the chromatic number of the network connectivity graph. The minimum number grows asymptotically at a logarithmic rate with the chromatic number, attesting to the good scalability of the spectrum allocation technique and its robustness to network topology changes. We designed a simple distributed and asynchronous algorithm by which a feasible spectrum allocation can be constructed given enough sub-bands.

Given a feasible spectrum allocation, we developed an analytical framework and a set of node-based distributed algorithms for optimally allocating transmission powers and traffic rates on active links. Such a framework is especially suitable for the design of wireless networks with frequency selective channels. We provided the conditions that an optimal power control and routing configuration must satisfy. We then designed a set of distributed power control and routing algorithms using the scaled gradient projection method. These algorithms can be iterated at individual nodes with little control overhead. Finally, we demonstrated that the algorithms asymptotically achieve the optimal configuration regardless of the initial condition and the order of iterating different algorithms.

-A Proof of Lemma 2

We provide the proof for the case g>⌊Q/2⌋𝑔𝑄2g>\lfloor Q/2\rfloor. The other case g<⌊Q/2⌋𝑔𝑄2g<\lfloor Q/2\rfloor can be seen as a corollary by taking complements of all subsets involved in the first case.

First notice that since g>⌊Q/2⌋𝑔𝑄2g>\lfloor Q/2\rfloor, there are K=(Qg−1)𝐾binomial𝑄𝑔1K={Q\choose{g-1}} distinct subsets C1,⋯,CKsubscript𝐶1⋯subscript𝐶𝐾C_{1},\cdots,C_{K} of cardinality g−1𝑔1g-1, where K≥k=(Qg)𝐾𝑘binomial𝑄𝑔K\geq k={Q\choose g}, the number of distinct subsets of cardinality g𝑔g. Hence, the claim makes intuitive sense.

Consider the bipartite graph consisting of {Bi}subscript𝐵𝑖\{B_{i}\} and {Cj}subscript𝐶𝑗\{C_{j}\} where a pair of Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} and Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j} are connected if and only if Cj⊂Bisubscript𝐶𝑗subscript𝐵𝑖C_{j}\subset B_{i}. In this case, Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j} is said to be a child of Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}, and Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} is said to be a parent of Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j}. It is easy to see that every Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i} has g𝑔g children and every Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j} has Q−g+1𝑄𝑔1Q-g+1 parents. Now the claim in the lemma is equivalent to the existence of a complete matching (of size k𝑘k) of {Bi}subscript𝐵𝑖\{B_{i}\} and {Cj}subscript𝐶𝑗\{C_{j}\} in the bipartite graph specified above. Because g>⌊Q/2⌋𝑔𝑄2g>\lfloor Q/2\rfloor implies that g≥Q+12𝑔𝑄12g\geq\frac{Q+1}{2}, the degree of any Bisubscript𝐵𝑖B_{i}, which is g𝑔g, is greater than or equal to Q−g+1𝑄𝑔1Q-g+1, the degree of any Cjsubscript𝐶𝑗C_{j}. In this case, a complete matching must exist by a corollary of Hall’s theorem (cf. Corollary 13.4 of [35]).

-B Proof of Lemma 3

Suppose {Bi}i∈𝒩subscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑖𝒩\{B_{i}\}_{i\in{\cal N}} is an optimal solution and |⋃iBi|=Qsubscript𝑖subscript𝐵𝑖𝑄\left|\bigcup_{i}B_{i}\right|=Q. If {Bi}subscript𝐵𝑖\{B_{i}\} does not have the property in the lemma, we can always modify it to {Bi∗}superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖\{B_{i}^{*}\} which satisfies the property with Q∗=|⋃iBi∗|superscript𝑄subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖Q^{*}=\left|\bigcup_{i}B_{i}^{*}\right| being less than or equal to Q𝑄Q. Hence, the lemma follows. Suppose we have a feasible solution ℬℬ{\cal B} consisting of a collection of N𝑁N subsets {Bi}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑖𝑖1𝑁\{B_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N}. If M>⌊Q/2⌋𝑀𝑄2M>\lfloor Q/2\rfloor, define 𝒩M≜{i∈𝒩:|Bi|=M}≜subscript𝒩𝑀conditional-set𝑖𝒩subscript𝐵𝑖𝑀{\cal N}_{M}\triangleq\{i\in{\cal N}:|B_{i}|=M\}, replace each Bjsubscript𝐵𝑗B_{j}, j∈𝒩M𝑗subscript𝒩𝑀j\in{\cal N}_{M}, by subset Bj′superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑗′B_{j}^{\prime} with cardinality M−1𝑀1M-1 such that Bj′⊂Bjsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑗′subscript𝐵𝑗B_{j}^{\prime}\subset B_{j} for all j∈𝒩M𝑗subscript𝒩𝑀j\in{\cal N}_{M}, and Bj′≠Bk′superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑗′superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘′B_{j}^{\prime}\neq B_{k}^{\prime} if and only if Bj≠Bksubscript𝐵𝑗subscript𝐵𝑘B_{j}\neq B_{k}. If the minimum and maximum cardinalities of the new collection of subsets are equal, we are done. Otherwise repeat the above procedure until we obtain an even collection of subsets. The iterations terminate in a finite number of steps since each iteration strictly reduces the difference between M𝑀M and m𝑚m.

It is implicit from (16) and (28) that δ​ρi​(q)=P¯i​[∑n∈𝒩Gi​nq​M​S​Gnq+γi​(q)]𝛿subscript𝜌𝑖𝑞subscript¯𝑃𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑛𝒩superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖𝑛𝑞𝑀𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑛𝑞subscript𝛾𝑖𝑞\delta\rho_{i}(q)=\bar{P}_{i}[\sum_{n\in{\cal N}}G_{in}^{q}MSG_{n}^{q}+\gamma_{i}(q)]. Thus, we have shown that the cost incurred by an arbitrary feasible configuration is greater than or equal to the cost by a configuration that satisfies the conditions in Theorem 2. So the proof is complete.
